copyright.text: Copyright 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy, effectiveness and safety of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end against human papillomavirus in males: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

paras: Background: Human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is safe and effective in preventing cervical cancer in females. As HPV infections can also induce cancers of the anus, penis and oral cavity, male @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is also advocated, but @hit_startsystematic reviews@hit_end on efficacy and safety in males are lacking. Methods: We performed a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end on the efficacy, effectiveness and safety of HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in males of any age. @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Central Register of Controlled Trials and ClinicalTrials.gov were searched from inception to April 2017. Results: We identified 5196 articles and seven studies (four randomized controlled trials (RCTs), three non-randomized studies) were included, comprising a total of 5294 participants. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end efficacy against at least 6-month persisting anogenital HPV 16 infections was 46.9% (95% confidence interval (CI) 28.6-60.8%), whereas efficacy against persisting oral infections was 88% (2-98%). A @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy of 61.9% (21.4-82.8%) and 46.8% (- 20 to -77.9%) was observed against @hit_startanal@hit_end intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 and grade 3 lesions, respectively. No meaningful estimates were available on @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy or effectiveness against penile intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 or 3, and no data were identified for @hit_startanal@hit_end, penile or head and neck squamous cell cancer. In participants who were HPV-seronegative and PCR-negative at enrolment, efficacy against all outcomes was higher as compared to seropositive and/or PCR-positive individuals. Risk of bias was low in three RCTs and high in one, while the three non-randomized studies were at serious to critical risk of bias. Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation evidence quality was moderate to low for most outcomes. Conclusions: HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in males is moderately effective against persistent anogenital HPV infection and high-grade @hit_startanal@hit_end intraepithelial lesions in studies where the population consists mainly of HPV-infected males. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end effectiveness was high in study groups comprising HPV-naïve males. This supports a recommendation for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end of boys before the onset of sexual activity with the goal of establishing optimal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-induced@hit_end protection. Mathematical modelling studies will still be needed to assess the effects of adding males to existing HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs in females.

titleText.ttltext: The health economics of cholera: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Technische Universtät Berlin, Department of Management in Health Care

paras: Background: Vibrio cholera is a major contributor of diarrheal illness that causes significant morbidity and mortality globally. While there is literature on the health economics of diarrheal illnesses more generally, few studies have quantified the cost-of-illness and cost-effectiveness of cholera-specific prevention and control interventions. The present @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end provides a comprehensive overview of the literature specific to cholera as it pertains to key health economic measures. Methods: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end was performed with no date restrictions up through February 2017 in @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Econlit, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, Web of Science, and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Review to identify relevant health economics of cholera literature. After removing duplicates, a total of 1993 studies were screened and coded independently by two reviewers, resulting in 22 relevant studies. Data on population, methods, and results (cost-of-illness and cost-effectiveness of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end) were compared by country/region. All costs were adjusted to 2017 USD for comparability. Results: Costs per cholera case were found to be rather low: <$100 per case in most settings, even when costs incurred by patients/families and lost productivity are considered. When wider socioeconomic costs are included, estimated costs are >$1000/case. There is adequate evidence to support the economic value of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end for the prevention and control of cholera when @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is targeted at high-incidence populations and/or areas with high case fatality rates due to cholera. When herd @hit_startimmunity@hit_end is considered, @hit_startvaccination@hit_end also becomes a cost-effective option for the general population and is comparable in cost-effectiveness to other routine immunizations. Conclusions: Cholera @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is a viable short-to-medium term option, especially as the upfront costs of building water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) infrastructure are considerably higher for countries that face a significant burden of cholera. While WASH may be the more cost-effective solution in the long-term when implemented properly, cholera @hit_startvaccination@hit_end can still be a feasible, cost-effective strategy.

titleText.ttltext: Application of E75 peptide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in breast cancer patients: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Cancer Research Center, Tehran University of Medical Sciences

paras: The E75 peptide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, derived from tumor-associated antigen HER2, is the most frequently studied anti-HER2 @hit_startvaccination@hit_end strategy for the treatment of breast cancer patients. It has been investigated in the several phases Ι/Π of the clinical trials and is currently being evaluated in a randomized multicenter phase III clinical trial. We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to clarify the outcomes of the E75 peptide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end including the therapeutic efficacy, the disease recurrence, the survival rate, and the side effects. Three peer-@hit_startreviewed literature@hit_end databases including the @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Web of Science, and Scopus were sought. Of 29 trials assessed for eligibility, 16 were considered based on our inclusion criteria. Statistical @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were performed by The Excel and STATA v.11.0. @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of delayed-type hypersensitivity)DTH(reactions and CD8@sup_begin+@sup_end-T cell levels, as immune responses, displayed the significant differences in the @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end groups compared to their non-@hit_startvaccinated@hit_end counterparts. In addition, the recurrence, and the overall and the disease-free survival were significantly different in the @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end subjects versus the control. Evaluation of the local and systemic toxicity of the E75 peptide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end demonstrated the minimal side effects. It seems that the E75 peptide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is safe and effective, and can be used for further randomized clinical trials.

titleText.ttltext: Racial/Ethnic Disparities in Influenza and Pneumococcal @hit_startVaccinations@hit_end Among Nursing Home Residents: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end

paras: This @hit_startsystematic review analyzes@hit_end research examining racial/ethnic disparities in influenza and pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage between White and racial/ethnic minority (Black and Hispanic) nursing home residents. A @hit_startreview@hit_end of the @hit_startliterature@hit_end for years 1966-2014 using @hit_startMedline@hit_end, Web of Science, and @hit_startPubMed@hit_end was conducted. The Epidemiological Appraisal Instrument was used to appraise the quality of the 13 included studies. Overall, articles were strong in reporting and data @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, but weak in sample selection and measurement quality. Disparities between @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage among racial/ethnic minorities versus Whites ranged from 2% to 20% for influenza and 6% to 15% for pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Researchers reported racial/ethnic minorities were more likely to refuse @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end and less likely to have @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end offered and their @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status tracked compared to Whites. Policies/strategies that focus on ensuring racial/ethnic minorities are offered influenza and pneumococcal @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end and their @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status are tracked in nursing homes are warranted. Updated evaluation on @hit_startvaccination@hit_end disparities is also needed.

titleText.ttltext: Hepatitis B virus infection among pregnant women in Ethiopia: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of prevalence studies

organizations: Mizan -Tepi University, Department of Public Health, College of Health Sciences

paras: Background: There are several epidemiological studies available on hepatitis B virus among pregnant women in Ethiopia. These individual studies revealed wide variation over time and across geographical areas. The aim of this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end is to estimate the overall prevalence of hepatitis B virus infection among pregnant women in Ethiopia. Methods: A comprehensive search of electronic databases including @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Popline, Lalicus, Ovid, MedNar, African Journal Online (AJOL) and advanced Google Scholar was conducted regardless of publication year from August 30, 2017 to September 25, 2017. The search was updated on January 02, 2018 to minimize time-lag bias. The methodological qualities of included studies were assessed using Joanna Briggs Institute @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-Analysis@hit_end of Statistics Assessment and Review Instruments. Results: Out of 103 studies, 17 studies with a total of 5629 pregnant women were included in the @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. The pooled prevalence of hepatitis B virus infection among pregnant women using random-effect model was 4.7%(95% CI 4.0-5.4%). The I@sup_begin2@sup_end statistics was I@sup_begin2@sup_end = 37.9%(p = 0.0575). Even though significant heterogeneity among studies was not detected, the I@sup_begin2@sup_end = 37.9% suggests medium heterogeneity. A subgroup @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end showed that study site, region, mean/median sample size, hepatitis B virus screening methods and methodological quality were not source of heterogeneity (p-difference > 0.05). Conclusion: This review shows an intermediate level of hepatitis B virus infection among pregnant women in Ethiopia. In addition to the current practice of child @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, routine and universal antenatal hepatitis B virus screening program need to be implemented.

titleText.ttltext: Cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end versus 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in an adult population in south Korea

organizations: Division of Infectious Dieases, Department of Internal Medicine, Guro Hospital, Korea University College of Medicine

paras: In South Korea, the National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program offers a 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PPSV23) for the elderly; however, the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PCV13) is not included, and @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is not offered to younger, at-risk populations. This study offers a comparative @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of PCV13 and PPSV23 in Korea's adults, stratified by age and risk group. A Markov model with a lifetime horizon was developed from the healthcare perspective. Data sources included the Health Insurance Review & Assessment Service, Korea Centre for Disease Control & Prevention and Korean medical institutions. An expert panel tested data validity. The CAPiTA trial and @hit_startCochrane meta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end were used to obtain @hit_startvaccine@hit_end effectiveness data. Regardless of co-morbidity, when the sequential PCV13-PPSV23 strategy was compared to that using PPSV23-only, in elderly populations, the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) was 3,300 USD per quality-adjusted life years (QALY). For the risk group aged ≥65 years, the ICER of the addition of PCV13 over the existing PPSV23-only strategy was 3,404 USD/QALY. However, on replacing PPSV23 with PCV13, for all elderly populations, an ICER of 1,421 USD/QALY resulted; for the risk group aged ≥65 years, the ICER was 1,736 USD/QALY. For the 18-64 year-old risk group, the sequential PCV13-PPSV23 strategy yielded an ICER of 3,629 USD/QALY over the PPSV23-only strategy, and 6,643 USD/QALY compared to no @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Thus, the PCV13→PPSV23 combination strategy for elderly populations was found to be a cost-effective alternative to the current National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program regardless of co-morbidity. This finding was the same as that for younger, at-risk populations.

titleText.ttltext: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end: The role of resident memory T cells in infectious diseases and their relevance for @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development

organizations: Centre for Biosecurity and Tropical Infectious Diseases, Australian Institute of Tropical Health and Medicine, James Cook University

paras: Background: Resident memory T cells have emerged as key players in the immune response generated against a number of pathogens. Their ability to take residence in non-lymphoid peripheral tissues allows for the rapid deployment of secondary effector responses at the site of pathogen entry. This ability to provide enhanced regional @hit_startimmunity@hit_end has gathered much attention, with the generation of resident memory T cells being the goal of many novel @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Objectives: This review aimed to systematically @hit_startanalyze@hit_end published literature investigating the role of resident memory T cells in human infectious diseases. Known effector responses mounted by these cells are summarized and key strategies that are potentially influential in the rational design of resident memory T cell inducing @hit_startvaccines@hit_end have also been highlighted. Methods: A Boolean search was applied to @hit_startMedline@hit_end, SCOPUS, and Web of Science. Studies that investigated the effector response generated by resident memory T cells and/or evaluated strategies for inducing these cells were included irrespective of published date. Studies must have utilized an established technique for identifying resident memory T cells such as T cell phenotyping. Results: While over 600 publications were revealed by the search, 147 articles were eligible for inclusion. The reference lists of included articles were also screened for other eligible publications. This resulted in the inclusion of publications that studied resident memory T cells in the context of over 25 human pathogens. The vast majority of studies were conducted in mouse models and demonstrated that resident memory T cells mount protective immune responses. Conclusion: Although the role resident memory T cells play in providing @hit_startimmunity@hit_end varies depending on the pathogen and anatomical location they resided in, the evidence overall suggests that these cells are vital for the timely and optimal protection against a number of infectious diseases. The induction of resident memory T cells should be further investigated and seriously considered when designing new @hit_startvaccines@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Safety and efficacy of durvalumab (MEDI4736) in various solid tumors

organizations: State Key Laboratory of Biotherapy and Cancer Center, West China Hospital, Sichuan University and Collaborative Innovation Center

paras: Introduction: The prominent immune checkpoint molecule, programmed cell death ligand-1 (PD-L1), is the object of increasing attention. Here, we report a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end investigating the safety and efficacy of durvalumab (MEDI4736), an inhibitor of PD-L1, in various solid tumors. Methods: A systematic search of @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and related articles was performed. Safety data were @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end using Comprehensive @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-Analysis@hit_end software program version 2. Ultimately, 17 studies with 1,529 patients were included in our @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. Results: The major adverse events associated with durvalumab were pruritus and fatigue, while pruritus, increased alanine transaminase, and increased aspartate aminotransferase were common among patients treated with a combination of durvalumab and tremelimumab. Higher PD-L1 expression was associated with a superior objective response rate. Conclusion: Durvalumab is safe in patients with many solid cancers and, in combination with tremelimumab, it has a tolerable safety profile and is associated with improved prognosis. PD-L1 expression is a biomarker of the efficacy of durvalumab.

titleText.ttltext: Caregiver recall in childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end surveys: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end of recall quality and use in low- and middle-income settings

organizations: Institute for Global Health, University College London
affiliation.addressPart: 3rd Floor, Institute of Child Health, 30 Guilford Street

paras: Introduction: High population coverage is key to the impact of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. However, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage estimates in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) have repeatedly been shown to be of poor quality. LMICs often rely on ‘caregiver recall’ of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, the validity and collection method of which remains uncertain. We aimed to critique the quality of caregiver recall and make recommendations for its collection and use. Methods: We performed a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end for methods assessing childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage in LMICs. We searched @hit_startMedline@hit_end using variations of the key terms: (child) AND (vaccinat@sup_begin∗@sup_end) AND (survey OR recall OR coverage) AND (reliab@sup_begin∗@sup_end OR valid@sup_begin∗@sup_end). We selected articles assessing the quality of recall in LMICs and extracted reported validity, reliability and completeness. We synthesised recommendations on collecting, @hit_startanalysing@hit_end and presenting caregiver recall for varying resource availabilities. Results: Of 1268 articles, 134 full texts were screened and eight were included for review. There was heterogeneity in study designs, ways of incorporating recall data and outcomes measured. Sensitivity of recall was 41–98%; specificity was 12–80%. There was a dearth of reliability measures and no consistent method for dealing with data incompleteness. Conclusion: There are quality concerns with caregiver recall and difficulty in assessing it given the lack of a ‘gold standard’ for @hit_startvaccine@hit_end status. To improve coverage estimates and the impact of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, caregiver recall should be used. Other recommendations include: recall is included for those presenting @hit_startvaccine@hit_end records; missing data is imputed; recall and record quality are assessed in a sub-sample; and sensitivity @hit_startanalyses@hit_end are performed.

titleText.ttltext: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end on the safety of newly adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end among older adults

organizations: P95, Epidemiology and Pharmacovigilance Consulting and Services

paras: Introduction: New adjuvants have been developed to improve the efficacy of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and for dose-sparing capacity and may overcome immuno senescence in the elderly. We reviewed the safety of newly-adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in older adults. Methods: We searched @hit_startMedline@hit_end for clinical trials (CTs) including new adjuvant systems (AS01, AS02, AS03, or MF59), used in older adults, published between 01/1995 and 09/2017. Safety outcomes were: serious adverse events (SAEs); solicited local and general AEs (reactogenicity); unsolicited AEs; and potentially immune-mediated diseases (pIMDs). Standard random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end were conducted by type of safety event and adjuvant type, reporting Relative Risks (RR) with 95% confidence intervals (95% CI). Results: We identified 1040 publications, from which we selected 7, 7, and 12 CTs on AS01/AS02, AS03 and MF59, respectively. 47,602 study participants received newly-adjuvanted @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and 44,521 control @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, or placebo. Rates of SAEs (RR = 0.99, 95% CI = 0.96–1.02), deaths (RR = 0.99, 95% CI = 0.92–1.06) and pIMDs (RR = 0.94, 95% CI = 0.79–1.1) were comparable in newly-adjuvanted and control groups. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end@hit_start-related@hit_end SAEs occurred in <1% of the subjects in both groups. The reactogenicity of AS01/AS02 and AS03 adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end was higher compared to control @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, whereas MF59-adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end resulted only in more pain. Grade 3 reactogenicity was reported infrequently, with fatigue (RR = 2.48, 95% CI = 1.69–3.64), headache (RR = 2.94, 95% CI = 1.24–6.95), and myalgia (RR = 2.68, 95% CI = 1.86–3.80) occurring more frequently in newly-adjuvanted groups. Unsolicited AEs occurred slightly more frequently in newly-adjuvanted groups (RR = 1.04, 95% CI = 1.00–1.08). Conclusions: Our review suggests that, within the clinical trial setting, the use of new adjuvants in older adults has not led to any safety concerns, with no increase in SAEs or fatalities. Higher rates for solicited AEs were observed, especially for AS01/AS02 and AS03 adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, but AEs were mostly mild and transient. Further evidence will need to come from the use of new adjuvants in the real-world setting, where larger numbers can be studied to potentially detect rare reactions.
